awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Fluctuations and dissipation in nonlinear mesoscopic vibrational systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical abstract 

Today's technology allows the fabrication of devices with sizes on the order of nanometers that are used in a variety of applications such as light modulation and mass measurements in labs-on-a-chip.  The functioning of these nano electro-mechanical systems, or NEMS, can currently be fairly well understood using the laws of classical mechanics first developed by Newton.  However, as the device size continues to shrink new effects will emerge that govern their behavior.  For very small devices Newton's laws are no longer valid and the more mysterious and counterintuitive laws of quantum mechanics will govern the behavior.  In addition, fluctuations and non-linearity's in the device will become more important.   This EAGER brings together an experimental and theoretical physicist to develop new analytical tools and experimental methods to understand, predict and control NEMS when fluctuations and non-linear behavior become important.  This will have important practical consequences as these devices are used for mass, charge and force measurements, accurate frequency sources and electro-optic modulators. Graduate students involved in this project will learn state of the art experimental and theoretical techniques and will gain valuable experience working in an experimental-theoretical collaboration.

Technical abstract 

NEMS are the best characterized platform for studies of quantum and classical fluctuations far from equilibrium, including such phenomena as interstate switching and optomechanical cooling and heating. However, there remain major questions concerning the very origin of the fluctuations and the mechanisms of dissipation in these systems, as well as the interplay of fluctuations, dissipation, and nonlinearity.  Conventional theories of open quantum and classical systems are insufficient, as they do not adequately describe substantially nonlinear vibrations and the effects of non-Gaussian fluctuations. The research supported by this grant will develop theoretical and experimental means for separating and identifying eigenfrequency fluctuations and studying their statistics and spectra. In turn, this will make it possible to establish their microscopic mechanism. In a broader context, the proposed studies pave the way to understanding general features of classical and quantum fluctuations away from thermal equilibrium using nonlinear NEMS driven by strong periodic fields.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report for the grant “EAGER: Fluctuations and dissipation in nonlinear mesoscopic vibrational system”

Nano- and micromechanical systems (NEMS and MEMS) have found numerous applications in modern technology, from navigation and communication systems to automotive systems to mass, force, and charge sensors. NEMS and MEMS also provide a platform for studying fundamental problems of science, from quantum and classical fluctuations away from thermal equilibrium to developing new means for quantum information processing. Critical for the applications is to understand the mechanisms that underlie the dynamics of NEMS and MEMS. In spite of the significant progress, there remain major questions concerning the very origin of the fluctuations and the mechanisms of dissipation in these systems, as well as the interplay of fluctuations, dissipation, and nonlinearity away from thermal equilibrium. The intellectual merits of the joint theoretical and experimental research supported by this grant centered at addressing these questions.

The broader impact of the work is determined by indicating ways that should enable a qualitative improvement of the NEMS characteristics related to the limitations imposed by eigenfrequency fluctuations. The results also directly bear on the characterization and improvement of superconducting electromagnetic cavities used in quantum information. The grant has supported in part two theory and one experimental graduate student; the theory students have received Ph D, with one of them moving to a postdoctoral position and the other to a position in industry.

The results have suggested a qualitatively new way of directly revealing and characterizing fluctuations of the frequency of a vibrational mode. They have also pointed to an important and hitherto overlooked major microscopic mechanism of frequency fluctuations. Along with this mechanism there was also understood a major microscopic mechanism of the vibration decay known as nonlinear friction. Universal scaling and several types of a nontrivial behavior were discovered in the quantum regime for periodically driven modes, which is immediately related to the application of such modes in quantum information. An anomalous phase diffusion was found and demonstrated in coupled resonators, which opens a way of correcting phase diffusion in NEMS and MEMS with an unprecedented precision. A qualitatively new application of NEMS and MEMS as signal detectors was suggested and the optimal detection regime was identified. These and other results have appeared in 10 papers published in top science journals and have been presented in a number of invited talks at national and international conferences.
